https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/job/gRPC_interop_pull_requests/15301/testReport/junit/(root)/tests/cloud_to_cloud_java_http2_server_max_streams/
This has been happening relatively often for a while now. Any plans/ideas? @ericgribkoff @ejona86
@dgquintas No ideas yet. I will prioritize looking into this and updating this thread.

I'm unable to reproduce these failures after running continuously for several hours locally.

I looked into the warning messages for "onStreamAllocated was not called, but it seems the stream is active" (https://github.com/grpc/grpc-java/issues/3007) and believe I have a fix for those, but I'm fairly certain the warnings are irrelevant to the actual test failures: this and the other java:http2 flakes all indicate that the Java client is timing out waiting for a response from the server. When this first appeared, I had thought this might be a test infrastructure problem, but the infrastructure seems far more reliable now and the same tests work reliably for the other languages.

Interestingly, it's not that Java can't connect to the server but that it doesn't seem to receive the same responses the other language clients are successfully getting. It's consistently just these three tests that fail (max streams, rst after data, and rst during data): the very similar rst after header seems to reliably pass. Tomorrow I'll have a more detailed look at the Python server and see if I can make any educated guesses about what might be going wrong by looking at the differences between the three rst stream tests.

> It's consistently just these three tests that fail (max streams, rst after data, and rst during data): the very similar rst after header seems to reliably pass. 

These are also the only tests with a timeout in the Java client, and it's only set to 5 seconds. It looks like these test cases sometimes take up to 2 minutes to pass for the other languages. Just submitted https://github.com/grpc/grpc-java/pull/3333 which bumps the timeout up to 180 seconds, and will monitor this to see if the change reduces the flakiness.
The tests have consistently passed since grpc/grpc-java#3333. Marking this resolved.
